title: Drip Nozzle (3/4 inch, 4 holes) - 3Dponics Vertical Garden

description.text: Screws on to bottle like a bottle cap and ensures that the water drips at a controlled rate. To attach to the next bottle, thread zip ties through the four holes. Fits 3/4-inch tubing (if you’re using tubing to transport the water to the plants). Know how to make this part better? Let us know! Join the 3Dponics online community: http://goo.gl/hYtFsC

TIPS (for MakerBot printers)  
-Low quality; 2 shells; 10% infill  
Tested on MakerBot Replicator 2 and 2x

comments.text:
Hi,
I tried printig the nozzle, but have some problems removing support material ( it's not easy getting it out of the big hole...). I would insert a little membrane (~0,5mm thick) at the top of the threaded area (close the little hole), so that there is a closed surface and you can bridge over that distance and no support material is needed.
Greetings,
Marius

author: 3dprintler

description.text:
Sick of hunting round the base of the cupboard under the sink for the roll of bin bags? I was.   
No longer!  
There's two versions of the boxy bit. One with text and cutouts and one without.

PRINTING:
The bracket needs support "everywhere" for the T section of the dovetail. Print with reasonable infill (25% plus) to give sufficient strength when wiggling out the support material.
I printed at 0.15 layers, 25% infill, 0.8mm shell, 80mm/s traverse for both. No extra platform adhesion necessary.
The box prints on its base and needs "touching build plate" supports for the rear mount. Its a slight pain getting it out too, but not impossible.
FITTING:
Mount the bracket using your favorite screws and then slide the box down the T bar. Nice tight interference fit. Fill with stuff.

Chattanooga Tennessee constructed with SRTM2STL using SRTM data from the Space Shuttle. Lookout mMountain and the Tennessee River show up very well. Amplification factor on elevation was 2.0. The source code for creating these files is available up on github under the GNU license. Go to github and search for SRTM2STL.

You may want to print this to be relatively small. I get warping using PLA and it gets bad when I try to print Raised Relief Maps that are big. I have had 'some' success with big maps. If you have a way to control warping you may also have better luck with big maps.

This mounts on the right side of the MakerBot Cupcake where the endstops used to go. You can create and attach anything, as long as it uses a matching hole pattern (see instructions).
The teardrop-shaped holes are my attempt at being clever to solve the overhang problem while printing horizontal holes.

Mount with two M3 bolts and nuts in the two holes on the right side of the Cupcake that are 20mm apart. The centers of the holes on the top of the mount are as follows: Base holes: M3, 20mm apart.
Top hole: M3, 5mm vertically from base holes.

description.text: I've taken Sample and Hold's lovely scan of Cory Doctorow and made it a little more printable. Details in Instructions. Now we just need glasses!

Steps I took to get this file:
  • Covert to .stl
  • Decimate down to 100k polygons in Meshlab
  • repair using Netfabb's clod service
  • rotate to match the 3D printing convention of Z+ = up
  • Cut off the overhang-y bottom parts
  • Scale by a factor of .5 so that it will fit in the envelope of most consumer printers
    • This should be directly printable without any modifications.

description.text: DIY gymnastics/fitness rings! Cut them (and the jigs) from 1/8" baltic birch plywood, glue them (using the jigs for alignment), clamp them, sand them like crazy. Then, you're ready for a great gymnastics rings workout.

I started from standard gymnastics rings dimensions (7" inside dia., 1/25" profile dia.), drafted them in Rhino, sliced them for laser cutting from 1/8" baltic birch plywood.
Update: the new v02 .dxf file includes a better jig design.

Hog's Hangout, Swamp Living Never Felt So Good Although lithophanes are normally printed flat, this one defies expectations and dares to be different. This does make illuminating it more challenging, but where there's a will, there's a way. A tube light works well, in this case a miniature light saber. This was a test to see how well a lithophane would come out when printed at 60 degrees. Unsurprisingly, most of the detail in the original is lost, but it came out pretty well if the lighting can be managed. The original image has been attached for reference.

Printed at 100% fill, one shell at 0.10 mm layer height on a replicator 2. Makeware estimated 7 hours, it took 9 hours.  
Like other lithophanes, this one is challenging to print. The narrow width leads to frequent start/stops and consequent extrusion failure. There are horizontal lines running across the entire width where extrusion was only partially successful. Not evident in these images, but the interior is scarred as if a sharp hook had been used to rip the surface -- not sure how that happened.  
After starting the print I realized that the one side was unsupported and, given the print time, there was a significant risk that it would detach from the build plate. I haven't printed the second one which is enclosed excepting a gap in the bottom to allow insertion of a light. It should not suffer from any detachment.  
The print actually adhered very well to the build plate and took most of the blue tape with it.

description.text: For me, what makes 3D printing so awesome is not just that you can make things yourself that you would have otherwise bought, but that you can make things that couldn't be made any other way. For this reason, I've been captivated by captured joints, where moving parts are printed together such that no assembly is required. This lampshade consists of 14 interlocking pieces printed at once. When you pull up on the top, the blossom opens, allowing more light out. See the video here: http://youtu.be/blEgWG9V9sA This lamp is my entry into ProtoParadigm's Winter Wonderland Contest, since when I'm struggling through a long, dark, Northwest winter, what I need is light and a reminder that the blossoms of spring will eventually arrive. I was inspired by http://www.mgxbymaterialise.com/limited-editions/mgxmodel/detail/detail/71, but I wanted to make a simpler, more organic model that wouldn't require a powder printer.

Choose one of the lampshades; the black one is Lamp_Opaque and the green one is Lamp_Translucent, which has a thin, solid inner surface instead of the grillwork, to act as a light diffuser when using translucent plastic.
Print the lampshade and the stand. I sliced them with Slic3r, which worked great. Make sure you have good retraction. I printed everything you see on my Replicator 1 in PLA at 120 mm/s using the Sailfish firmware. I print on unheated blue painters tape, which kept everything well adhered to the build platform.
When the lampshade is finished printing, remove it from the platform and carefully push up on the bottom center parts while pulling down on the outer ring. You may need to slice a few strings between the petals to allow them to separate. Once you get it open all the way, exercise it a few times and cut out any remaining strings. It should move quite freely. 
The stand is made to accept a standard hollow, threaded rod that lamps are often mounted with (at least in the US). You just need to find a small lamp socket and cord to attach. I used a standard candelabra socket and an LED bulb. You can use anything, so long as it's less than 34mm in diameter. I recommend LEDs, since they are low power and so won't soften the plastic. However, small LED bulbs are strangely hard to find. Of course, you could always make your own.
Once you install the bulb, slip the shade down over it and press it into the stand (it's just a conical press-fit). This way you can pry the shade back off to change the bulb. 
The bottom of the stand is solid so that you can pour sand in if you're worried about it tipping over. The holes in the stand are designed to encourage cooling airflow past the bulb. I'm also trying something new: I signed my name to the bottom of the stand. When my dad was a potter, he always stamped his name on the bottom of his pots, so I thought I would try the same thing. I'm interested to hear if any of you have comments on this method of attribution.

comments.text: What do you mean "until I got temperature control on my heated bed"? If you can turn heat on at all, you should be able to set its temperature. What printer and software are you using? In GCODE you should see something like M190 S110, which would set the heated bed to 110 degrees, and if you change 110 to, say, 50, that should make PLA happy. Lots of people are printing PLA on an unheated print bed, but I've had much better luck printing on 40-50 degree heated bed than unheated.
comments.author: zaaphod

comments.text: I have an airwolf 3d printer, my heated bed is not software controlled, it's just wired to a fixed 12v power supply.   I'm using gen 6 electronics, and that does not support heated bed, I'll have to upgrade to a gen 6 deluxe if I want software heated bed.   I'm using repetier host and firmware, and that will support a heated bed if I I upgrade the electronics.  I could also put an independent temperature control on the bed... I just have to get a round to it.   I may just get some PLA and try it non-heated.

author: TheCase

description.text:
Cuburr combines a traditional three-piece-burr puzzle (the inner part) with a six-piece-burr puzzle (the surfaces) by connecting them with flexible hinges.
http://mysd300.blogspot.com/2011/07/flexible-burrcuburr.html
I designed this model to exploit the unique traits of my SD300, an LOM 3D printer. LOM, or Laminated Object Manufacturing, builds 3D objects by bonding thin sheets of material (paper or plastic) and cutting the contours into each layer one-at-a-time The walls are 0.2mm to 0.4mm thick.so it requires a printer capable of making thin flexible walls.

The whole model is less than 1mm high, and works well with material 0.16 to 0.18mm thick. Probably not suitable for extruder-based machines with most materials. If you have a Solido SD300 or Invision LD, you can use the file cuburr_set2.sdm which already has all three pieces arranged on the table with peeling cuts. I recommend using the No Z-Fold option so for easy peeling.
To solve it as a puzzle you'll need to bend, fold, and twist the pieces to get them together into the shape of a cube.

title: Keystem (nonzero) for Monroe K- or KA-series calculators

description.text: This is a keystem for Monroe K- or KA-series mechanical calculators, which were manufactured between 1920 and 1928. The keystem for the zero digit is different than this, but if you have a metal brake then you can bend this to make the zero keystem (see instructions).

The files are 1 unit = 0.001 inches.  
To make a zero keystem out of this, with the thick leg of the part on the right, scribe a bending line about 0.205 inches from the bottom. Using a metal brake, line up the scribed line with the edge of the clamp, then bend a 1/16 inch radius.  
This will work out far better than 3D printing the zero keystem version of this part, since you can't really make bends in OpenSCAD. And Blender is a bit beyond me :)

remixed_from.title: 2X Extruder Upgrade for Raffle Alu-Dual Cooling Block

description.text: This is a remix of 256754, and credit should go to the author of that thing. Here in the UK we can't get the recommended spring from the US suppliers (at least not without jumping thru hoops!), and whilst other alternatives are available this modification provides a means of applying pressure to the filament via small M4 bolts. If you need springs for this design take a look at the following: http://e3d-online.com/RepRap-Spares-Mechanical/Compression-spring-21x7.5mm This update has installed holes in the arms (for M4 bolts) together with hex cutouts (for M4 nuts). You can still use the springs as needed, however for problem filaments such as nylon more pressure might be required - and that pressure can be applied by tightening the bolts. You require 2 M4 bolts (minimum 30mm long) and 2 M4 nuts. One thing to be wary of is that the bolts could collide with the left side of the 2X frame when the X axis reaches its left side limit, so do check that before you commit the installation. There is no such issue on the right side. In use you can use this design with or without the bolts - the extruders will work fine with just the springs, so it is feasible to add the bolt on the left side only if that's the extruder where you use problem filaments.
Applied enhancements to STL files using TinkerCad.

author: Kokinchan

title: End Stop for Emerson Clamping Tool Guide

description.text: E. Emerson End Stop for Straight Edge Clamping Tool Guide, upgrade part XCSB. For Contractor Series with recessed tracks. Check out Wide Jaws: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:379387

This is an end stop for Contractor Series E. Emerson Straight Edge Clamping Tool Guide.
The part is reversible by only switching the adjustable end. The adjustable piece is a 5/16" Hex Bolt with 2 matching nuts (minimum length being 1"). One must be hot pressed into the space on the end stop itself. The other nut is placed on the bolt to tighten the position so that the end stop can be perfectly set to desired measurement.
*You may not want to put an extra nut on the other side if you prefer using a longer 5/16" adjustable bolt.
The 2 (#8 - 32 x 1.25") machine screws the fit through the knobs upside down to lock the end stop in the recessed tracking. The nut for each of these is also hot pressed into the end stop knobs in order to create a tight fit and a solid clamping mechanism to hold the end stop in place. (Look at picture for configuration)
There are small guides that match up with the ruler on the Clamping Guide, although not sure how useful. Parts:
5/16" x 1" Hex Head Bolt (x1)
5/16" Nut (x3)
8 - 32 Machine Screw (x2)
8 - 32 Nut (x2)
Suggest higher infill so that piece last longer.
Fitting is really tight and can be threaded or heated for better results.

title: Gear Cookie Cutters
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Three gear-shaped cookie cutters for producing culinary mechanisms. The gears have the same diametral pitch, 8 teeth/inch, so they all mesh together properly. Files are posted for 16, 24 and 32 toothed gears, with mating diameters of 2, 3 and 4 inches respectively.
The center holes are 3/8" and should allow the baked cookies to rotate easily around a pencil shaft. The gear teeth have an involute profile with a pressure angle of 20 deg (in case you care). If the gear teeth break off when you're playing with your edible gears, that's just how the cookie crumbles!

My test parts were printed at a 0.01" layer height out of ABS.  No support material was needed.  
The thin "cutting" part of these cookie cutters is 0.02".  The intention here was to set your printer to a 0.02" contour path (deposited plastic) width so that the thin "cutting" portion is only a single contour wide.

This is spare part for children trike bycicle which fixes the wheel on the axis. I've measured and modelled the one instead of lost one.

I've printed on dualstrusion, ABS 10 perimeters with 100% infill,
with support of PLA.
However it was a problem moving from internal hole to the next solid.
To solve it I've added 0.5mm outside wall from ABS also (so that it works as a stick base together with PLA support). Need to set 'external perimeter first' in slick3r.
Print, then remove supporting wall, then remove PLA support.
Add wire spring made from 2mm wire (bycicle's spoke fits ideally!)

Free Art in the heart of Vienna by Ulrike Truger against racism.
The pictures and the 3D-scan have been captured on 29th June, 2014 by me. Further information about the case which influenced Truger to offer this stone:
http://blog.mondediplo.net/IMG/pdf/deportation-omofuma.pdf (English)
http://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marcus_Omofuma (German only :( )

I went to the place where the scultpure can be found. Then I took a piece of chalk and with it I was able to mark every spot where I had to shoot a photo (for a 3D-scan you require photos taken in 360 degrees around the object). Sadly the stone was too high (nearly 3 meters) for me to take pictures from the top, that's why there are artifacts at the top of the model (and there was no chair or something that I could have climbed on). After taking the pictures I uploaded them on an online free platform, where the 3D-scan has been made.

title: Barnett Bandit Crossbow - Foam Dart Mod

description.text:
This is a printable track that will allow a Barnett Bandit toy crossbow to fire Nerf style foam darts. They track track simply slides onto the existing track and is held in place with friction at the front, making it easily removable. It works well with Nerf Elite style darts. The range is comparable to other single-plunger style blasters, but it is surprisingly accurate, and quiet. In the world of office warfare, it makes a great silent sniper weapon. As a side note, the Bandit crossbow fires the new Nerf Mega darts perfectly without the track. This makes the crossbow a nice variable-ammo blaster.
http://youtu.be/fjki7n5gaz4

Printed in PLA on a Makerbot Replicator 2 at medium quality. The track is broken into 2 pieces with small mortise and tenon joint for alignment and strength at the joint. I used a small amount of Plastruct to weld the joint. http://amzn.to/1ohFbvE If printed vertically as indicated in the stl files, it does not require any support. I also included the .skp files, so feel free to remix and improve.

remixed_from.author: jonaskuehling
remixed_from.title: Y Carriage Mounting Frame for Slim LM8UU Holders

title: Modified Y-Carriage for maximal distance, LM8UU

description.text:
This is a modified version of Jonas Kuehling's "Y Carriage Mounting Frame for Slim LM8UU Holders". It includes two mounting tools: snap_on.stl and rod_end.stl. The idea is to have a maximum distance of the smooth rods by printing two connected LM8UU holders diagonal on the print bed. You can make a larger print bed for your next new 3D printer with this diagonal technique. This technique causes a poor alignment of the two holder pairs. But the additional mounting tools will help there. If the smooth rods are not parallel, a rod fixation clamp can break apart after a while and bearings may fail sooner. Update:
Added a new modification of the LM8UU holder. The enforced side walls reduce the risk of breaking. You should be able to adapt the nuttraps to you needs.

Adjust the OpenSCAD file and change the frame_length and rod_dist values.
To use the OpenSCAD file you need the extra "lm8uu-holder-slim_v1-1.scad" from the ancestor version.
Keep in mind the maximum of your print bed diagonal size. The STL-files are for a rod distance of 138 mm from center points. (There is no specific reason for 138 mm.) You can print the connecting snap_on part, if you need more help for the alignment of the holders. The rod_end part is for checking that the rods are parallel.
To get a more precise alignment, mount all bearings and the smooth rods before the fixation on the bottom plate. Update:
  • added a M3 thumb cap
  • added a T5 belt tensioner

title: Front Mount Stabiliser and Y-switch reverse.

description.text:
Have been using Jon Lawrence 'Printrbot Simple, 300mm Y Axis-No Sag!', thingi
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:242185. With the 'ExtendYFront2013Fan.STL'.
The top rail feels loose now so I decided to tie it on with a block and screws.
Whilst about it I put a bolt holder and made a switch holder so that I could reverse the Y-switch from front to back.
Printrbot seem to have made this change, and it's probably easier to go with, rather than resist. I thought it more logical before, cartesian co-ordinates, bottom left etc.
You don't have to take anything apart to fit this.
Anyway, the frame feels more solid on the top now.

I tapped the two holes in the main block, 3mm, what else! These holes go all the way through, and if you have longer screws you could go all the way through it, and have a nut at the end. I used 20mm long screws. They felt long enough. UPDATE: 24/7/14, having used this or sometime now, I would recommend getting long screws, so that the whole thing binds together, but that might be just my problem with too low a temperature during printing. I used 50mm long screws, fairly sure you could get away with 40mm.
The clamp is a snug fit, but there are screw holes on top if you need them. I didn't in the end, it felt tight enough.
Put a lock nut on the bolt to counter vibration movement.
I used the old switch from the Z-stop, not used, now I have auto-level probe, the current Y-switch can stay where it is for now. It's very tight in there! I used the original screws too. Forcing them to cut a thread, half a turn forward, quarter turn back.
I was able to slip a cable tie at the front end to hold it down, but thought not everyone will be able to, so have uploaded a long front one that can be tied lower down. I haven't tried this, let me know if
it's a problem.
The cable can go down beside the Y-motor, and take that route, to keep it tidy.

description.text:
A cable clip / holder capable of keeping three cables from falling from the table.
UPDATE: Added a hollow version. It allows to print the holder and fill it with a heavier material to improve friction. There is also a file for the base to cap up the holder after filling.

Printing is pretty straightforward. Should be printed at lowish speed, at least the top part. Otherwise support might be necessary and the top will not print cleanly. 
To prevent the clip itself from sliding from the surface, use either double sided tape or some sort of anti slip or high friction material. I glued tennis bat wrapping material to the bottom of it and while far from perfect, it does the job for me.
The hollow version should be printed with support.

This thing is a bracket used to provide enough surface area for using a double adhesive tape to mount the IR sensor against a surface. The IR sensor from Adafruit (http://adafru.it/1031) is hollow at the

author: hyperair

title: Filter holder: welding glass as neutral density Filter (ND) for photography (for Nikon 18-105/18-135)

description.text:
This is a filter holder for some Nikon lenses. It let's you attach a welding glass to your lens to act as a neutral density filter, in order to get longer shutter speeds. (see this Flickr group for examples: http://www.flickr.com/groups/weldingmaskglassfilter/) Welding glass is used in all kinds of metal welding techniques, to protect your eyes from the light. The glass is very cheap and can make an inexpensive neutral density filter for photography (means you can use very long shutter speeds during daylight to e.g. make water very silky or do amazing stuff with the clouds).
For this we need a rectangular shape of glass as used for electrical welding. The glass has to be 110mm wide to fit the holder. I guess there are different sizes but hopefully they are a bit standardized. I bought my glass at a local store for 3â‚¬. You can also buy ND filters in photography stores, but they can get very expensive, 100â‚¬ and more. You will get much better quality for your money, but the aim here was to get it done cheap. Note: One of the pictures is an example photo, taken with the filter.

Now, how do we attach this welding glass to the camera? Many people are using rubber bands and while I am a big fan of improvised photo gear, I also felt that this was not a good solution. Why? Because I want to frame my picture and set focus without the filter. Then I'll mount the filter and the viewfinder of my camera gets pitch black â€“ good for taking the picture, bad for framing and focusing. Thats how you do it â€“ It reads long, but it is dead simple:
0) Use ABS if possible. I printed two on a Makerbot Replicator and ABS turned out ok. I did not test PLA, but I guess ABS is better because it is more flexible. (I typically print this one with these settings: Infill 35%, ABS at 226Â°C extruder and 110Â°C heated plate.
1) Print the mount raftless. Make sure that the first layer will be very flat on the bed. Otherwise the mount will probably sit too firm on the lens and you'll have to sand it a bit.
2) Print the filter holding plate raftless*
3) You might need to carve out the filter holding plate a bit with a knife to make the filter fit. If the glass sits too lose, glue a piece of clothing in there.
4) Snap both pieces together (see https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eiquqivFiRk). They are designed to press fit. The backside is a bit rounded so, thats the side that has to do in first. Make sure the small pockets of the mount are exactly Top/Bottom. If unsure, connect the mount to your lens and see how the holder plate has to go on there. If the mount sits to firmly at the lens, use sandpaper and sand off a bit from the part that goes to the camera (make the mount thinner).
5) Done. Slide your glass into the holder. Point your camera to something, focus, snap the Filter holder to your lens and give it a go. This works probably for all lenses, that use the Nikon HB-32 mount for lens shades â€“ yes, it snaps into the lens shade bajonett, it is not screwed into the filter thread. It should work for the following lenses:
Nikon 18-105 (I tested mine with this one)
Nikon 18-135 (Not tested. But a friend owns one of these, so I'll ask him to try it)
Nikon 18-70 (Not tested yet) == OPTIONAL =========================
  • Maybe there is a chance to print this raftless but with support. It might work like this, but this is not yet tested:
    a) Edit your slicing profiles
    b) Duplicate your default slicing profile (Name it something like "Support without raft")
    c) Edit the created duplicate
    d) Seleft the "craft" and then "raft" radio buttons
    e) Search for "Base Layers" and "Interface Layers" and set both to "0"
    f) Save the profile.
    g) Generate GCode, using this profile, select Use Raft and Use Support. Select "use full support". Just exterior will give you basically the same result as raftless.

This is 2Watt 800RPM push blower for my beer can Stirling engine. ItÂ´s pushing fair amount of air with silent operation. It would work with 3 or 4 blades, but with 6 its looking more respectable. Also spinner is more for looks than aerodynamics here. It is out from CH10SM airfoil data (slightly modified and high angle of attack for lower power and speeds). Time to share if someone finds a use for this - under 1000 RPM, low power and accelerations only. You can just imagine to fly with this - unfortunately design is no good for that and will be dissapointment with whatever material and engine.
For general home use this fan is quite "directional" with efficient narrow air flow several meters away... Now I revealed you that this is really not optimized for doing anything useful. Take care.

This is put into upwright position and shorted to fit all in one Huxley bed.
I had problems with one part and I added some support holding it upright. It came out with 1 perimeter infill 20% with slow speed very light and quite easily blade will break. This more like a safety feature for my fingers. I increased for 2 perimeters in order to have material for some sanding and its much easier to solder parts togeather. Print the parts.
-clean support
-use temperature controlled soldering tip around 240Â°C for blade assembly. Just short touches from here and there - avoid heating too much. Good way is to put up temperature to 260-300Â°C to make things happen faster. If you think about painting a smooth surface on blades this is right moment to do sanding on blades before there is no other things attached on them.
I find out that VERY coarse sanding paper actually works to PLA and after that you can go for a smoother one also water seems to work with sanding - plastic comes out of small particles like dust and no melting. My sanding tests are just with hand. Before attaching blades to their bases put them standing side by side on the table. This way you can easilly adjust the blade angles same level. Now its time to stop and think a second or two in what direction your are rotating and direction of air flow. Mine is pushing air. While making you mind its time to search M4 nut and even better a really a long one - I used 16mm long from some electronics parts. This is for attach axle and spinner from other end. On spinner I used piece of plastic M4 thread. I used epoxy AND some superglue AND soldering tip heat to attach all blades to hexagonal part in one go. (I just hate to make glueing jigs...). I have M4 threads in engine axle so I just turned propeller in place and attached spinner to finalize the look. Final checks for free rotation and ready to start engines.
In the picture the prop is idling with prototype engine and help of tiny blue flame approx 600rpm already moving fair amount of air... I do not know the quality of STLÂ´s, but these I used.
Sorry no scad... original model is not totally perfect eighther... IÂ´m not going to develop this prop any further - if I got new engine running I propably need to design a new prop for it.

title: Mounting-adaptor for Universal Paste Extruder to fit Mendel90

description.text: This is an adaptor to be able to fit the Universal Paste Extruder onto a Mendel90 printer. Extruder: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:20733 Please note: This is uploaded by request. I have not tweaked the design to make it perfect. I just printed one and fixed the problems by hand afterwards. Some filing and such is required to make it work. You can probably see what's done in the photos. It's nothing major, you're done in five minutes. The design is also based on what I hand available, therefor allen-screws are used instead of hex. placed so that they can't be held when screwing them down. Not very optimal, but it works. See instructions for how to make them sit better. Also: Please note that mounting this extruder makes the working-area approx. 25mm smaller. Edit that in your Marlin-firmware or be very careful not to print to large prints, that will make the X-axis run into the end.

Some nuts and bolts are required. What you need is four M4 nuts, one M3 nut, one ~10mm M3 screw, two ~20mm M4 allen-screws and two ~15mm allen screws.  
The two screws holding the plate down to the printer can not be reached when mounting, so to make them not being able to spin freely:  
File one or two dents into the head of the screw. Then put them into the holes of the adaptor, and melt some plastic down into the dents, so that the plastic holds the screws down.  
Everything else can probably be seen in the pictures.

2x Quanum 4008 brushless motors
1x controller board, 2-axis
1x carbon shock absorbing plate with rubber dampers
4x 16 mm alu. Tarot tube clamp
4x 12 mm tube clamp
...some srews and bolts Update: first test with Sony NEX 5: http://youtu.be/yjy8nDaOKOk update 2015-02-15:
I had problems with the gimbal when using it with the heavier Sony Nex. Sad to say I replaced it with it a DYS because of vibrations I could not get rid of. Probably because the construction is not stiff enough and I used too light rubber vibration dampers. Update 2016-01-19:
with some more experience with the Alexmos in retrospect I think the vibrations were caused by bad PID values or bad connection of the IMU sensor. For controller, a stand alone nulled version Alexmoss controller was used Some small faults in the 3D print design:
  • diameter around motors of the could be 0.5 mm bigger (tight fit; had to use aceton)
  • cable location differ 90 degrees on some Quanum motors; The position seems not consistant in respect of the mounting thread holes
    • The design was printed with a Leapfrog, without support material. More footage:
    http://youtu.be/FselVdqGLIA (stabilised)
    https://plus.google.com/photos/108394968200012243536/albums/6053086198104189761?authkey=CKeMrr-c9LfGAQ

Great design! I have a few questions.

comments.author: Elfirico

comments.text:
Yes, the camera foot plate must be prepared for balancing. I have had to drill some holes and use filling plates to find the sweet spot.
The aluminium tube clamps can be found on ebay; they don't cost much.
The tube clamps of the print design was a worry when I was designing but they work perfect: no rotatation, strong grip.

Back in 1970, my older brother Asgeir Ulsnes was about to become a ceramist. He created this work of art as a school assignment. It is a gargoyle type of creature, and a pun to the danish name of the Seawolf - "Sea Cat".
44 years later, I found it in his lovely garden, sitting under an elder tree, which coincidentally smells like - Cat pee :-)
Scanned using 123D Catch, edited in MeshMixer, printed 0.1 Sky Blue ABS, using a Solidoodle 4 printer.

title: sx350 box smaller tactical switch and 510 connector hole

description.text:
this is an alternate version to the previous design which is a lot smaller in dimensions. i was able to take 1cm off the depth...note that the tactical switch hole and the 510 are just incisions and may need to be dremeled wider also a small incision may be needed for the battery holder to connect to the 510 base or the battery holder may need to be modified ...
the parts i had in mind are found here:
Tacticle switch:
http://www.ebay.com.au/itm/231254950279?ssPageName=STRK:MEWNX:IT&_trksid=p3984.m1497.l2649
Magnets for the lid:
https://www.fasttech.com/p/1555101
510 connector:
http://www.varitube.com/510-Connector--Spring-Loaded-Center-Pin_p_141.html
please post pictures of your designs once finished..i would love to see how you guys went with this design.
